timeline.bodyText: Rather than using readAllBytes, it's probably safer to use something like FileInputStream to read at most 32 bytes, and then detect if there's extra unread data and, if so, throw an error.
timeline.author: mbaxter

replies.bodyText:
Great idea. What if we just read in the first 32 and ignored the rest?
Thinking out loud... I think that would error in the case of users adding 32 chars and a new line char?
replies.author: EdwardPrentice

replies.bodyText: That's a good point.  I think to start, I'd err on the side of being strict (fail to read from the file if the format is unexpected).  This could help prevent errors where the node operator has pointed to the wrong file, for example.  We want to be pretty careful about what we post to the chain - no way to remove it later :D
replies.author: mbaxter

replies.bodyText: We could always add some validation at startup - try to read from the provided file and if it fails, refuse to start.  This would give the node operator a heads up that the format is wrong.
replies.author: mbaxter

replies.bodyText: I've put a stricter check in. Of course we can't rely on failing at start up because the file can change subsequently. Let me know what you think.

timeline.bodyText: InputStream (and the underlying file descriptor) is not closed after calling readNBytes. This would cause Validator.getGraffiti() to repeatedly open the graffiti file when producing a block. Of course, during finalization the FD would be closed, but I'd assume it's better practice to explicitely close it.
timeline.author: systemfreund

timeline.bodyText:
A couple of boundary conditions:

Empty file
file of exactly 32 bytes
file of 33 bytes

For the 33 bytes i'd probably just shrink the 64 bytes file, but the test at the actual bound is worthwhile to demonstrate.
I'd leave the current sample of 10 bytes, the middle sizes are most likely scenarios.
Given the file is read as bytes, could write 0x00 to file, this could be the '32 bytes' test from above... it would show that we can read 32 bytes, and that that 32 bytes can be 0x00.
Empty file and Bytes32.ZERO in file should both result in Bytes32.ZERO so it should be asserted against that value once it's been read.
I like the tests overall, but boundaries tend to be where things can get fragile :)

timeline.bodyText:
this is all just really a question and some thoughts to ponder:
this puts an interesting twist on the concept of 'file is too big' really... If it's a file with a bunch of whitespace that puts it over, this would strip that whitespace and you might be left with valid graffiti? I guess what I'm thinking is the poor person that has '\n' at the end of their file that pushes them over the graffiti limit, but equally accidentally putting whitespace before?
I'm not sure what the answer is, just a question, because really if we're stripping we could potentially not check file size up front but rather attempt to get 32 bytes of graffiti from the file.
so realistic use cases

bytes32\n
 bytes32 (leading space)
\nbytes32\n

Currently these stripped characters would be basically 'your loss', I guess, you have a \n at the end, so only get 31 bytes of graffiti, but this does seem like you'd potentially have a frustrating time figuring out where that byte disappears...

replies.bodyText:
Yep i think reading a few extra bytes and allowing the fast fail is still good, and it just means we need to check the graffiti is only 32 bytes once we're done and potentially throw the error at the end too...
I completely agree that reading a large buffer wouldn't be great, I was thinking just being nice and allowing a few bytes either side, so this is good.
The other scenario (i think there's a ticket somewhere!) is to read binary from file....
In that scenario we wouldn't be able to do this conversion at all, so it'd become a moot point and we'd just read the 32 bytes max and move on, but i think given this ticket is looking at text, we get that in and worry about the other scenario later...
